title: 110_hr2499
content: The Act may be cited as the "SBDC Colonias Outreach Act of 2007" and includes findings and purposes. The Congress finds that Colonias in Texas, New Mexico, Arizona, and California lack basic services and economic opportunities, with high unemployment rates and low average salaries. There are approximately 3,000 Colonias in the Southwest with nearly three quarters of a million residents. Improving living conditions in Colonias requires addressing both infrastructure and economic growth. The Small Business Development Center program provides cost-effective resources and technical assistance to stimulate economic development and create new small businesses in Colonias, where job opportunities are limited and services are scarce. The Small Business Development Center program aims to support new and existing small businesses in Colonias by providing management, technical, and research assistance, ensuring full access to business counseling and technical assistance. Small Business Development Center program provides assistance to Colonias for new and existing small businesses. Section 21(a) of the Small Business Act is amended to allow eligible states along the US-Mexico border to apply for additional grants to assist individuals in Colonias with small business startups and expansions. Applicants for grants under this program must submit an application to the Administration, detailing their goals, ability to provide services in Colonias, proposed Small Business Development Center site location, and the required grant funding amount. The program requires applicants to comply with all grant requirements, with exceptions for matching funds. The maximum grant amount is $300,000 per fiscal year. The Administration will issue final regulations after consulting with the recognized Association. The Administration will issue final regulations for Small Business Development Centers, including standards for educational, technical, and support services, as well as work plan requirements. Definitions include the term 'Colonias' as a community within 150 miles. The term 'Colonias' refers to communities within 150 miles of the United States-Mexico border with a population of less than 10,000, majority low-income families, and lacking basic physical infrastructure. The term 'Colonias' refers to communities near the US-Mexico border with less than 10,000 people, mostly low-income families, lacking basic infrastructure like housing, potable water, sewage systems, and paved streets. Authorization of $7,000,000 for fiscal years 2008-2010 is provided for these services with funding limitations specified. Funding of $7,000,000 for fiscal years 2008-2010 is authorized for communities near the US-Mexico border, known as 'Colonias', to improve basic infrastructure.
